title: Abalakov thread
definition: A type of abseiling point used especially in winter and ice climbing. Also known as V-thread.

title: Ablation zone
definition: The area of a glacier where yearly melting meets or exceeds the annual snow fall.

title: Abseil
definition: The process by which a climber can descend a fixed rope. Also known as Rappel.

title: ACR (Alpine Cock Ring)
definition: An anchor method similar to a cordelette but that is dynamically equalizing. It employs a cord and a rappel ring.

title: Add-On
definition: A climbing game, played indoors, were climbers take turns creating a route usually adding two moves at a time. Climbers usually play until they reach a certain amount of falls.

title: Adze
definition: A thin blade mounted perpendicular to the handle on an ice axe that can be used for chopping footholds.

title: Aid climbing
definition: A style of climbing in which standing on or pulling oneself up via devices attached to fixed or placed protection is used to make upward progress.

title: Alpine climbing
definition: Generally climbing in the mountains. Probably includes a mixture of ice climbing and dry-tooling. Alpine style generally means carrying all gear in a backpack even for multi day climbs.

title: Alpine knee
definition: To use your knee as a way to gain ground on a climb.

title: Alpine start
definition: To make an efficient start on a long climb by packing all your gear the previous evening and starting early in the morning, usually well before sunrise.

title: Altitude sickness
definition: A medical condition that is often observed at high altitudes. Also known as Acute mountain sickness, or AMS.[4]  Typical symptoms include headache and nausea.  Symptoms dissipate quickly by reducing altitude.

title: American death triangle
definition: An anchor which is created by connecting a closed loop of cord or webbing between two points of protection, and then suspending the rope from a carabiner clipped to only one strand of said anchor.  This creates a triangular shape in the webbing or cord, which places massively multiplied inward forces on the protection, making it a dangerous, ineffective anchor.

title: Anchor
definition: An arrangement of one or (usually) more pieces of gear set up to support the weight of a belay or top rope.

title: Approach
definition: The path or route to the start of a technical climb. Although this is generally a walk or, at most, a scramble it is occasionally as hazardous as the climb itself.

title: Arête
definition:
A small ridge-like feature or a sharp outward facing corner on a steep rock face
Arête, a narrow ridge of rock formed by glacial erosion
A method of indoor climbing, in which one is able to use such a corner as a hold. See also dihedral.

title: Arm bar
definition: Jamming an arm into a crack and locking it into place.

title: Arqué
definition: (from the French word meaning arched) Used to describe crimping. In this position typically the first set of knuckles are hyperextended and the second have a sharp angle of about 90 degrees. This combines muscular effort with soft tissue tensions in order to apply the load. When used often, this position has been known to over-stress the tendons in fingers and lead to injuries.

title: Ascend
definition: To climb a rope using aid device.

title: Ascender
definition: A device for ascending on a rope.

title: Aspect
definition: The direction in which a slope faces.[5]

title: ATC
definition: A proprietary belay device manufactured by Black Diamond. Has become common term for any tubular belay devices. ATC originally stood for 'Air Traffic Controller'.

title: Automatic belay
definition: A fast method for setting up a two-point anchor in sport climbing, using the climbing rope to attach to the anchor points.

title: Austrian floss
definition: When a climber falls in a manner where the rope that they are attached to runs through their legs; upon falling, the rope tightens and suspends the climber via the rope rather than the harness.

title: "B"-grade
definition: A grading system for bouldering problems, invented by John Gill. Now largely superseded by the "V" grading system.

title: Bachar ladder
definition: A piece of training equipment used to improve campusing and core strength.

title: Back-clipping
definition: A potentially hazardous mistake that can be made while lead climbing. The rope is clipped into a quickdraw such that the leader's end runs underneath the quickdraw as opposed to over top of it.  If the leader falls, the rope may fold directly over the gate causing it to open and release the rope from the carabiner.

title: Bail
definition: To retreat from a climb.

title: Ball Nut
definition: A type of aid protection consisting of a nut and a movable ball.[6]

title: Barn-door
definition: If all points of contact climber has with the wall are on a straight axis, or close to it, his body might swing uncontrollably downward around this axis, like a door on a hinge.

title: Bashie
definition: A copperhead intended for pounding into a crack

title: Belay
definition: To protect a roped climber from falling by passing the rope through, or around, any type of friction enhancing belay device.  Before belay devices were invented, the rope was simply passed around the belayer's hips to create friction.

title: Belay device
definition: A mechanical device used to create friction when belaying by putting bends in the rope. Many types of belay devices exist, including ATC, grigri, Reverso, Sticht plate, eight and tuber. Some belay devices may also be used as descenders. A Munter hitch can sometimes be used instead of a belay device.

title: Belay Loop
definition: The strongest point on the harness.  This is the loop you use your belay device on.  You should not tie anything around the belay loop such as a daisy chain or sling.  The belay loop will wear more quickly.

title: Belay off
definition: Called by belayer to confirm belay has been removed from climbing rope.  Response to Off belay request.

title: Belay on
definition: Called by belayer to confirm belay has been (re)applied to climbing rope.  Response to On belay request.

title: Belay slave
definition: Someone that volunteers for, or is tricked into, repeated belaying duties without partaking in any of the actual climbing.

title: Belay station
definition: Place where the belayer is belaying, while anchored to the rock or other objects.[7]

title: Benightment
definition: An unscheduled overnight bivouac often due to an epic.

title: Bergschrund (or schrund)
definition: A crevasse that forms on the upper portion of a glacier where the moving section pulls away from the headwall. Also called a 'shrund.

title: Beta
definition: Advice on how to successfully complete (or protect) a particular climbing route, boulder problem, or crux sequence. Some climbers believe that beta 'taints' an ascent.

title: Beta flash
definition: The clean ascent of a climb on the first attempt, having previously obtained beta or while having beta shouted up from the ground en route.  Also see on-sight.

title: Bicycle
definition: A technique used to keep the feet on when climbing on overhangs. One foot is placed on a foothold and the other foot is placed behind the foothold in a toe hook position. The climber can now squeeze the hold between the feet.

title: Bidoigt
definition: (French "two fingers") A climbing hold, typically a pocket or hueco, that has enough room for two fingers. See also mono.

title: Big wall
definition: A climb on which most parties will spend more than one day. Big wall style generally refers to hauling the needed gear (food, water, sleeping bags) in a haulbag. Instead of carrying the gear on their person, the climbers put it in the haul bag and raise it in between pitches.

title: Biner
definition: See Carabiner.

title: Bivy (or bivvy)
definition: From the French "bivouac".  A camp, or the act of camping, overnight while still on a climbing route off the ground.  May involve nothing more than lying down or sitting on a rock ledge without any sleeping gear.  When there is no rock ledge available, such as on a sheer vertical wall, a portaledge that hangs from anchors on the wall can be used.

title: Bivy-bag
definition: A lightweight garment or sack offering full-body protection from wind and rain.

title: Bollard
definition: A large knob of rock or ice used as a belay anchor.

title: Bolt
definition: A point of protection permanently installed in a hole drilled into the rock, to which a metal hanger is attached, having a hole for a carabiner or ring.

title: Bolt chopping
definition: The deliberate and destructive removal of one or more bolts.

title: Bomb-proof anchor
definition: A totally secure anchor. Also known as bomber. Bomber can also refer to a particularly solid handhold or foothold (a "Bomber Jug")

title: Book or open book
definition: An inside angle in the rock. See also dihedral.

title: Booty
definition: Gear left behind at a climbing area.

title: Bosun's chair
definition: To reduce pains from heavy-duty climbing using a harness; such as long-time belaying or bolting a new route, climbers attach their harness with a special type of chair, which is usually light and has multiple high endurance straps and buckles. Similar types are also used in industrial climbing. Also another name for a bowline on a bight, a rescue knot.

title: Bouldering
definition: The practice of climbing on large boulders. Typically this is close to the ground, so protection takes the form of crash pads and spotting instead of belay ropes.

title: Bridging
definition: see Stemming

title: Bucket
definition: A large handhold.

title: Bumbly
definition: Beginner or otherwise incompetent climber.

title: Bummer
definition: A slang word, referring to a difficult or uncomfortable hold, often one that tears the skin on the hand.

title: Bump
definition: A climbing technique wherein a hand or foot is moved to one hold then quickly moved up immediately to a further hold. This is often done over short distances advancing from an inferior hold to a superior one.

title: Buildering
definition: The art of climbing on buildings, which is often illegal.

title: Buttress
definition: A prominent feature that juts out from a rock or mountain.

title: Cairn
definition: A distinctive pile of stones placed to designate a summit or mark a trail, often above the treeline.

title: Cam
definition: A spring-loaded device used as protection.

title: Camming
definition: Motion or position where rotation of a piece of equipment or body part presses it tight against a rock, creating friction and holding it in place. As in Spring-loaded camming device, Heel-Toe Camming,[8] or knee bar camming.[9]

title: Campus
definition: The act of climbing without using any feet.

title: Campus board
definition: Training equipment used to build finger strength and strong arm lock-offs.

title: Carabiner
definition: Metal rings with spring-loaded gates, used as connectors. Usually oval or roughly D shaped. Also known as crab or biner (pronounced kar-uh-bee-ner).

title: Chalk
definition: A compound used to improve grip by absorbing sweat. It is actually gymnastics chalk, usually magnesium carbonate. Its use is controversial in some areas.

title: Chalk bag
definition: A hand-sized holder for a climber's chalk that is usually carried on a chalkbelt for easy access during a climb.

title: Chest jam
definition: Jamming the torso into a wide crack, for resting.

title: Cheese Grater
definition: A sliding fall down a slab style climb.

title: Chicken head
definition: see bollard, horn.

title: Chicken Wing
definition: This is a crack climbing technique. A hand is placed on one side of the crack and the shoulder on the other.

title: Chimney
definition:
A rock cleft with vertical sides mostly parallel, large enough to fit the climber's body into. To climb such a structure, the climber often uses his head, back and feet to apply opposite pressure on the vertical walls.
The process of using such a technique (chimneying).

title: Chipping
definition: Improving a hold by permanently altering the rock, which is considered unethical and unacceptable.

title: Chock
definition:
A mechanical device, or a wedge, used as anchors in cracks.
A naturally occurring stone wedged in a crack.

title: Choss
definition: Loose or "rotten" rock.

title: Classification
definition: See Grade.

title: Clawing
definition: Use of front points of crampons, ice axe pick and ice hammer pick to climb a slope.

title: Clean
definition:
To remove equipment from a route.
A route that is free of loose vegetation and rocks.
To complete a climb without falling or resting on the rope. Also see redpoint.
In aid climbing, abbreviated "C", a route that does not require the use of a hammer or any invasive addition of protection (such as pitons or copperheads) into the rock (see protection).

title: Cleaning tool
definition: A device for removing jammed equipment, especially nuts, from a route. Also known as a nut key or nut tool.

title: Climbing area
definition: A region that is plentiful with climbing routes.

title: Climbing command
definition: A short phrase used for communication between a climber and a belayer.

title: Climbing gym
definition: Specialized indoor climbing centres. See gym climbing. (Usually just called a 'climbing wall' in Britain).

title: Climbing shoe
definition: Footwear designed specifically for climbing. Usually well fitting, with a rubber sole.

title: Climbing technique
definition: Particular techniques, or moves, commonly applied in climbing.

title: Climbing wall
definition: Artificial rock, typically in a climbing gym.

title: Clipping in
definition: The process of attaching to belay lines or anchors for protection.

title: Clipstick
definition: See Stick clip.

title: Col
definition: A small pass or "saddle" between two peaks. Excellent for navigation as when standing on one it's always down in two, opposite, directions and up in the two directions in between those.

title: Cold shuts
definition: Industrial hardware used to link or repair steel chains, occasionally adapted by climbers as repel anchors.[10] Cold shuts can be either open, shut or welded. Open cold shuts are the unaltered hardware, which is hammered closed and sometimes welded, resulting in more secure anchors.[11]

title: Copperhead
definition: A small nut with a head made of soft metal on a loop of wire.

title: Cord lock
definition: a lock or toggle used to fasten cords with gloved hands. Used on most mountaineering gear.

title: Cordelette
definition: A long loop of accessory cord used to tie into multiple anchor points.

title: Corner
definition: An inside corner of rock, the opposite to an arête (UK). See Dihedral.

title: Cornice
definition: An overhanging edge of snow on a ridge.

title: Couloir
definition: A steep gully or gorge frequently filled with snow or ice.

title: Cowbell
definition: Another name for a hexcentric, due to the noise they make when hung together on a harness.

title: Crack climbing
definition: To ascend on a rock face by wedging body parts into cracks, i.e. not face climbing. See jamming and chimney.

title: Crag
definition: A small area with climbing routes, often just a small cliff face or a few boulders.

title: Crampons
definition: Metal framework with spikes attached to boots to increase safety on snow and ice.

title: Cramponing
definition:
Using crampons to ascend or descend on ice, preferably with maximum number of points of the crampon into the ice for weight distribution.
Accidentally piercing something with a crampon spike.

title: Crank
definition: To pull on a hold as hard as possible.

title: Crash pad
definition: A thick mat used to soften landings or to cover hazardous objects in the event of a fall. See: Bouldering mat

title: Crater
definition: Hitting the ground at the end of a fall instead of being caught by the rope.

title: Crimp
definition:
A hold which is only just big enough to be grasped with the tips of the fingers.
The process of holding onto a crimp.

title: Crux
definition: The most difficult portion of a climb.

title: Cup
definition: A hand grip which is squeezed, over the top or around the side, between the fingers and palm, forming a cup shape with the hand, or applying this type of hold on any protrusion or feature. More commonly known as guppy.

title: Cut-loose
definition: Where a climber's feet swing away from the rock on overhanging terrain, leaving the climber hanging only by their hands. Also known as "Cutting feet."

title: Cwm
definition: (Welsh) A hanging valley, or cirque—a steep-walled semicircular basin in a mountain—sometimes containing a lake; also known as a corrie.

title: Dab
definition: A term in bouldering to accidentally use another route while trying to ascend a route.

title: Daisy chain
definition: A special purpose type of sling with multiple sewn or tied loops, used in aid and big wall climbing. It is designed to hold a climber's bodyweight, rather than arrest a fall, and while the sling as a whole will have a strength rating comparable to that of a standard sling, but the individual side loops (pockets) will typically have much lower ratings. This is because a load between the two strength ratings could cause the pocket stitching to break, allowing the attachment device, typically a carabiner, to slide to the end of the sling before being halted by the greater strength of the webbing material itself.

title: Dapper
definition: Referring to the quality of a hold/route. That climb was absolutely dapper.

title: Dead Ball
definition: Type of High Ball boulder, where one can possibly die when falling from above.

title: Dead hang
definition: To hang limp, such that weight is held by ligament tension rather than muscles.

title: Deadman anchor
definition: An object buried into snow to serve as an anchor for an attached rope. One common type of such an anchor is the snow fluke.

title: Deadpoint
definition: A controlled dynamic motion in which the hold is grabbed with one hand at the apex of upward motion of the body, while one or both feet and the other hand maintain contact with the rock. Dynamic motions in which both feet leave the rock are typically called dynos.

title: Deck
definition:
The ground.
To hit the ground, usually the outcome of a fall.

title: Deep Water Soloing
definition: Free climbing an area that overhangs a deep enough body of water to allow for a safe fall. Often abbreviated DWS.

title: Descender
definition: A device for controlled descent on a rope. Also called a rappel device. Many belay devices may be used as descenders, including ATCs, figure eights, or even carabiners. See rappel.

title: Desmond
definition: A ground fall (from Desmond Dekker, a reggae artist and 'to deck').

title: Dexamethasone
definition: A pharmaceutical drug used in the treatment of high altitude cerebral edema as well as high altitude pulmonary edema. It is commonly carried on mountain climbing expeditions to help climbers deal with altitude sickness.[4]  Also known as "dex".

title: Dialled
definition: To have complete understanding of a particular climbing move or route.

title: Diamox
definition: A drug used to inhibit the onset of altitude sickness. Otherwise known as acetazolamide.[4]

title: Dièdre
definition: A dihedral.

title: Dihedral
definition: An inside corner of rock, with more than a 90-degree angle between the faces. See also corner and arête.

title: Direct aid
definition: See aid climbing

title: Dirtbag
definition: climbers living cheaply and supporting themselves through odd jobs in order to maximize the amount of time climbing. Well known practitioners of this lifestyle include Jan and Herb Conn or Fred Beckey.

title: Double Ropes or Half Ropes
definition: System where the climber is using two thin ropes instead of one thicker one. Double ropes are often used by trad and alpine climbers. They help managing the rope drag, reduce the chances for accidental cutting of the rope by sharp rock edges, and allows full pitch rappeling. Unlike twin ropes, double ropes can be clipped separately into different pieces.[12]

title: Double Rope Technique (DRT)
definition: The term denotes the use of double ropes.

title: Doubled Rope Technique (DdRT)
definition: A method used primarily by tree climbers where the rope passes over a support/limb and continuously slides over the limb as the climber ascends or descends.

title: Downclimb
definition: To descend by climbing downward, typically after completing a climb.

title: Drop Knee
definition: See Egyptian.

title: Drag or rope drag
definition: Rope drag occurs when the friction generated from the rope running over the rock and through the quickdraws builds up to the point where it is difficult move or to pull up the rope to clip into protection. There are several ways to prevent rope drag: protection placement that minimizes zig-zaging of the rope and potential for rope being pinched or hooked on a rock, use of long quickdraws like 24 inch alpine draws and use of double ropes.[13][14]

title: Drilled baby angle  or Drilled Pitons
definition: Type of anchor sometimes used in sandstone or other soft rock instead of bolts. The anchor consist of baby angle piton hammered into drilled hole, which some climbers believe is stronger in soft rock than expansion bolts, which can crack the rock. They were especially popular on desert routes in the US and can be still found on many routes.[15][16]

title: Dry Fire
definition: One or both hand(s) blows off a hold usually while chalked (dry). As your hand(s) blow off and skid across the hold (as if they are rubbing against sand paper) it results in a painful burning feeling (fire).

title: Dry-tooling
definition: Using tools for ice climbing like crampons and ice axes on rock, i.e., not on ice.

title: Dülfersitz
definition: A method of rappelling, without mechanical tools, where the uphill rope is straddled by the climber then looped around a hip, across the chest, over the opposite (weak) shoulder, and held with the downhill (strong) hand to adjust the shoulder friction and thus the descending speed.

title: Dynamic belay
definition: Technique of stopping a long fall using smooth braking to reduce stress on the protection points and avoid unnecessary trauma from an abrupt stop.

title: Dynamic rope
definition: A slightly elastic rope that softens falls to some extent. Also tend to be damaged less severely by heavy loads. Compare with static rope.

title: Dynamic motion
definition: Any move in which body momentum is used to grab a hold that would otherwise be out of reach. As opposed to static technique where three-point suspension and slow, controlled movement is the rule. When both feet leave the rock, it is called a dyno. When one or both feet maintain contact with the rock, it is called a deadpoint.

title: Dynamite starfish
definition: Tightly gripping handholds, simultaneously flagging out both legs then proceeding to violently kick downwards and inwards in a desperate attempt to produce upwards motion; making the climber resemble an explosive bottom feeder[citation needed].

title: Dyno
definition: A dynamic motion in which both feet will leave the rock face and return again once the target hold is caught. Non-climbers would call it a jump or a leap.

title: Edge
definition: A thin ledge on the rock.

title: Edging
definition: Using the edge of the climbing shoe on a foothold. In the absence of footholds, smearing is used.

title: Egyptian
definition: Method for reducing muscle strain in arms when holding a side grip. One knee ends up in a lower position with the body twisted towards the other leg. It can give a longer reach as the body and shoulders twist towards a hold. Also known as a "drop knee."

title: Egyptian bridging
definition: The same position as bridging or chimneying, but with one leg in front and one behind the body.

title: Eight-thousander
definition: A mountain whose elevation exceeds 8,000 metres above sea level.

title: Eliminate
definition: A bouldering move or series of moves in which either certain holds are placed 'off bounds' or other artificial restrictions are imposed.

title: Elvis legs
definition: Wobbly knees resulting from tired legs. See Sewing machine leg.

title: Epic
definition: An ordinary climb rendered difficult by a dangerous combination of weather, injuries, darkness, lack of preparedness or other adverse factors.  See Punter.

title: ERNEST
definition: Acronym for the important points to consider when building anchors. The acronym stands for Equalised, Redundant, No Extension, Strong, and Timely. See also SERENE.

title: European Death Knot (EDK)
definition: A flat overhand used to join a pair of ropes for retrievable abseils.  So named as the technique originated in Europe and the Americans initially distrusted it.

title: Exposure
definition:
Empty space below a climber, usually referring to a great distance a climber is above the ground or large ledge, or the psychological sense of this distance due to being unprotected, or because the rock angles away due to climbing an arête or overhang.
Hypothermia resulting from prolonged exposure to cold, wind and rain.

title: Extreme
definition: Part of UK adjectival grading system, originally short for extremely / exceptionally severe (XS); now split numerically into E1, E2, etc.

title: Face climbing
definition: To ascend a vertical rock face using finger holds, edges and smears, i.e. not crack climbing.

title: Fall
definition: To unintentionally descend using gravity as an aid. Hopefully stopped by a rope.

title: Feet follow
definition: An instruction on indoor bouldering routes requiring foot movements match preceding hand movements, with no intermediate moves.

title: Feature
definition: A protrusion or indentation on an indoor climbing wall which is permanently moulded into the wall itself.

title: Via Ferrata
definition: A route on a mountain where the safety is provided by steel ropes or chains, permanently fixated to the rock. The progression is often aided by artificial steps or ladders. Typically found in the Alps, also called Klettersteig.

title: Figure four
definition: Advanced climbing technique where the climber hooks a leg over the opposite arm, and then pushes down with this leg to achieve a greater vertical reach. Requires strength and a solid handhold.

title: Figure eight
definition: A belay device or descender shaped like an "8".

title: Figure-eight knot
definition: A knot commonly used to secure the climber's harness to the climbing rope.

title: Finger jam or Finger lock
definition: A type of jam using the finger. See climbing technique.

title: Finger board
definition: Training equipment used to build finger strength.

title: First ascensionist
definition: The person who performed the first ascent.

title: First ascent (FA)
definition: The first successful completion of a route.

title: First free ascent (FFA)
definition: First ascent without aid.

title: Fist jam
definition: A type of jam using the hand. See climbing technique.

title: Fixed rope
definition: A rope which has a fixed attachment point. Commonly used for abseiling or aid climbing.

title: Flagging
definition:
Climbing technique where a leg is held in a position to maintain balance, rather than to support weight.  Often useful to prevent barn-dooring. There are three types of flagging:
Normal flag: Where the flagging foot stays on the same side (e.g. flagging with the right foot out to the right side of the body)
Reverse inside flag: Where the flagging foot is crossed in front of the foot that is on a foothold
Reverse outside flag: Where the flagging foot is crossed behind the foot that is on a foothold

title: Flake
definition:
A thin slab of rock detached from the main face.
A method of untangling a rope in which the rope is run through the climber's hands and allowed to fall into a pile on the ground.  Useful when preparing a rope for coiling, or before starting a lead climb, to ensure the rope is fed cleanly and without twists.  Often called "flaking out" a rope.

title: Flapper
definition: An injury consisting of a piece of loose (flapping) skin. A climber will usually just repair these with sticky tape or super glue.

title: Flash
definition: To successfully and cleanly complete a climbing route on the first attempt after having received beta of some form.  Also refers to an ascent of this type.  For ascents on the first attempt without receiving beta see on-sight.

title: Flat-lander
definition: Non-climber.

title: Flute
definition: A usually insecure fin or flake of rock or ice.

title: Follow
definition: What the second does.

title: Font
definition: The French bouldering grading system.

title: Foot jam
definition: Also known as the heel-to-toe jam.  It involves jamming the foot into a larger crack by twisting the foot into place, the contact with the crack being on the heel and toes.

title: Fourteener
definition: Mountain that tops 14,000 feet (4,300 m) in the contiguous United States.

title: Free base
definition: Climbing with your only protection being a parachute that is deployed in the event of a fall. A combination of free soloing, and BASE jumping.

title: Free climbing
definition:
Climbing without unnatural aids, other than used for protection.
Often incorrectly used by non-climbers as a synonym for soloing.

title: Free solo
definition: Climbing without aid or protection. This typically means climbing without a rope.

title: French free
definition: Also known as French climbing, or French freeing, it is the use of aid climbing techniques to bypass a section due to climbing difficulty, rock conditions, etc.; typically for only a short section of the total climb.[17]

title: Frenchies
definition: An exercise used to develop lock-off strength consisting of pull-ups that stop with the elbows locked at angles between 20 and 160 degrees.

title: Friable
definition: Delicate and easily broken rock, often dangerous.

title: Friction
definition: Climbing technique relying on the friction between the sloped rock and the sole of the shoe to support the climber's weight, as opposed using holds or edges, cracks, etc.

title: Friend
definition: A name brand of a type of spring-loaded camming device (SLCD) made by Wild Country, sometimes used to refer to any type of spring-loaded camming device.

title: Gaston
definition: A climbing grip using one hand with the thumb down and elbow out, often thought of as a reverse side pull. The grip maintains friction against a hold by pressing outward toward the elbow.

title: Gate Flutter
definition: The action of the gate on a carabiner opening during a fall.

title: Gendarme
definition: A pinnacle or isolated rock tower frequently encountered along a ridge.

title: Geneva rappel
definition: A modified dulfersitz rappel using the hip and downhill arm for friction, rather than the chest and shoulder, offering less complexity, but less friction and less control. 'Geneva Style' is also a description used in Australia for what is commonly referred to elsewhere as 'Australian Rappelling'.

title: Glacier travel
definition: walking or climbing on a glacier; a rope is usually used to arrest falls into crevasses, but protection is not used.

title: Glissade
definition: A usually voluntary act of sliding down a steep slope of snow.

title: Golden Retriever
definition: When a climber is cleaning a route and forgets to pull out a piece or unclip the rope and begins to climb above the piece rendering the top rope ineffective.

title: Gorp
definition: Trail mix for periodic nibbling to keep high energy level between meals on long climbs or hikes. The name comes from "good old raisins and peanuts."[18]

title: Grade
definition:
Intended as an objective measure of the technical difficulty of a particular climb or bouldering problem. More often is highly subjective, however.
The slope of an incline. (Grade (geography))

title: Graunchy
definition: A route (often off-width) requiring the use of unconventional and uncomfortable techniques.

title: Green Point
definition: Climbing a sport route with the use of traditional gear.

title: Grigri
definition: A belay device designed to be easy to use and safer for beginners because it is assisted-braking under load. Invented and manufactured by Petzl. Many experienced climbers advocate the use of an atc type device for beginners.

title: Gripped
definition: Scared. Also over gripping the rock.

title: Gronked
definition: Accidentally going off-route while leading and becoming lost on a rock face in an area much more difficult than the climb being attempted. The word arises from the climb "Gronk" in Avon Gorge which is notorious for this.

title: Grovel
definition:
To climb with obviously poor style or technique.
A climbing route judged to be without redeeming virtue.

title: Gumby
definition: An inexperienced, unknowledgeable and oblivious climber; is a derogatory term. Gumbies are incapable of learning.

title: Guppy
definition: Synonym for cup, commonly used in bouldering.

title: Gym climbing
definition: Climbing indoors, on artificial climbing walls. This is typically for training but many people consider this a worthwhile activity in its own right.

title: Grease ball
definition: A route that has become climbed excessively, causing the rock to become slippery or "greasy".

title: HACE
definition: High Altitude Cerebral Edema – a severe, and often fatal, form of altitude sickness.[4]

title: Hamster
definition: The act of pulling oneself up with both arms parallel in front of your chest. Resembles a Hamster during feeding. That sloper required some hamstering to get to the next move.

title: Hand jam
definition: Making progress by inserting the hand (usually vertically with the thumb uppermost) into a crack and then pushing the thumb downwards towards the palm. This expands the hand and can make a highly secure placement. In the UK this move was credited with facilitating the advances in free climbing in the late 1940s and 50s made by climbers such as Joe Brown and Don Whillans although they did not invent it.'

title: Hand traverse
definition: Traversing without any definitive footholds, i.e. smearing or heelhooking.

title: Hangdog
definition: While lead climbing or on top rope, to hang on the rope or a piece of protection for a rest.

title: Hanging belay
definition: Belaying at a point such that the belayer is suspended.

title: HAPE
definition: High Altitude Pulmonary Edema – a serious form of altitude sickness.[4]

title: Harness
definition: A sewn nylon webbing device worn around the waist and thighs that is designed to allow a person to safely hang suspended in the air.

title: Haul bag
definition: A large and often unwieldy bag into which supplies and climbing equipment may be thrown.

title: Headpoint
definition: The practice of top-roping a hard trad route before leading it cleanly.

title: Headwall
definition: A region at the top of a cliff or rock face that steepens dramatically.

title: Heel hook
definition:
Heel hook 
Using the back of the heel to apply pressure to a hold, for balance or leverage; this technique requires pulling with the heel of a foot by flexing the hamstring. This technique is notable since in most forms of climbing one uses the toes to push.

title: Heel-toe
definition: A combination of a toe hook and heel hook. Also known as a heel-toe cam, involves using opposing pressure from the toes and heel between two holds to hold the body on the wall.

title: Helmet
definition: A personal protective device to protect the wearer's head from rocks, debris, equipment, or falls. Also known as a brain bucket or skid lid.

title: Hexcentric
definition: A protective device. It is an eccentric hexagonal nut attached to a wire loop. The nut is inserted into a crack and it holds through counter-pressure. Often just called hex.

title: High Ball
definition: A tall boulder problem. Falling becomes more dangerous due to the increase in height.

title: High Point
definition:
1. The highest point ever reached on a climb.
2. A personal highest point ever reached.

title: Himalaism
definition: Climbing grown in the Himalayas. In a broader sense this Himalayan mountaineering climbing, similar as to the nature of climbing in the Himalayas, but also grown in other high mountains, where the height of the peaks above 7000 meters above sea level are the Karakoram, Kunlun, Hindu Kush, Pamir, Tien Shan, Daxue Shan.

title: Hold
definition: A place to temporarily cling, grip, jam, press, or stand in the process of climbing.

title: HMS Carabiner
definition: A round-ended carabiner for use with a Munter hitch (from the German name for the hitch; Halbmastwurfsicherung).

title: Honed
definition: To be in peak mental and physical fitness for climbing.

title: Hook
definition:
Equipment used in aid climbing.
A climbing technique involving hooking a heel or toe against a hold in order to balance or to provide additional support.

title: Horn
definition: Large, pointed protrusion of rock that can be slung.  Typically also makes a good handhold.  Known in the UK as a "Spike". See bollard, chicken head.

title: Hueco
definition: (Spanish hueco "hole") A climbing hold consisting of a pocket in the rock, typically round and deep and featuring a positive lip.  Huecos vary in size from accommodating a single finger (this is also called a "mono") to large enough to fit one's entire body.  The term hueco entered the jargon of rock climbers from the Texas climbing area Hueco Tanks that is famous for this sort of hold.

title: Ice axe
definition: A handy tool for safety and balance, having a pick/adze head and a spike at the opposite end of a shaft.

title: Ice hammer
definition: A lightweight ice axe with a hammer/pick head on a short handle and no spike.

title: Ice piton
definition: Long, wide, serrated piton once used for weak protection on ice.

title: Ice screw
definition: A screw used to protect a climb over steep ice or for setting up a crevasse rescue system. The strongest and most reliable is the modern tubular ice screw which ranges in length from 10[19] to 23 cm.

title: Ice tool
definition: A specialized elaboration of the modern ice axe (and often described broadly as an ice axe or technical axe), used in ice climbing, mostly for the more difficult configurations.

title: Indoor climbing
definition: See gym climbing.

title: Jack Flash
definition: Climbing something second go.

title: Jamming
definition: Wedging a body part into a crack.

title: Jib
definition: A particularly small foothold, usually only large enough for the big toe, sometimes relying heavily on friction to support weight.

title: John Travolta
definition: Stabilizing a mantle by pushing one or two fingers against a crimp with the arm outstreched over the head (referring to dancemoves in Saturday Night Fever).

title: Jug
definition: A shortened term for Jug Hold, both noun and verb.

title: Jug hold
definition: A large, easily held hold. Also known simply as a jug.

title: Jumar
definition:
A type of mechanical ascender.
To ascend a rope using a mechanical ascender.

title: Karen
definition: See Cairn.

title: Klemheist knot
definition: An alternative to the Prusik knot, useful when the climber is short of cord but has plenty of webbing.

title: Knee Bar or Kneebar
definition: Involves camming your lower thigh or knee against a protruding section of rock, usually with the foot pushing against an opposing hold. Kneebars can be very secure and are one of few ways to get a no-hand rest on overhanging rock. They also can provide additional hold on a climb.[9][20]

title: Knee Drop
definition: See Egyptian.

title: Knots
definition: Climbers rely on many different knots for anchoring oneself to a mountain, joining two ropes together, slings for climbing up the rope, etc.

title: Laybacking or liebacking
definition: Climbing a vertical edge by side-pulling the edge with both hands and relying on friction or very small holds for the feet.

title: Lead climbing
definition: A form of climbing in which the climber clips the belay rope into quickdraws or similar equipment attached to the wall by means of anchors. In traditional climbing, the climber also needs to place anchors and quickdraws. In sport climbing, the anchors are typically preplaced, and the quickdraws may either be preplaced or placed by the climber.

title: Leader Fall
definition: A fall while lead climbing. A fall from above the climber's last piece of protection. The falling leader will fall at least twice the distance back to his or her last piece, plus slack and rope stretch.

title: Leashless
definition: Ice climbing with your axes not being attached to your wrist, if you drop them they're gone, but the trade off is greater mobility

title: Leavittation
definition: A technique used to climb off-width cracks pioneered by Randy Leavitt and Tony Yaniro, the technique uses alternating hand/fist stacks and leg/calf locks.

title: Liquid Chalk
definition: A liquid form of chalk with a longer hold time than normal chalk. It is used on very hard routes and competitions, where the act of rechalking requires too much energy or time.

title: Locking carabiner
definition: A carabiner with a locking gate, to prevent accidental release of the rope.

title: Lock-off
definition: Using tendon strength to support weight on a handhold without tiring muscles too much.

title: Low-Angle
definition: A face climb that is less than vertical; the opposite of an overhang or roof. The same as "slab".

title: Mantel (abbreviation of mantelshelf)
definition: A move used to surmount a ledge or feature in the rock in the absence of any useful holds directly above. It involves pushing down on a ledge or feature instead of pulling oneself up. In ice climbing, manteling is done by moving the hands from the shaft to the top of the ice tool and pushing down on the head of the tool.

title: Mantle
definition: The external covering of a climbing rope. Climbing ropes use kernmantle construction consisting of a kern (or core) for strength and an external sheath called the mantle.

title: Match
definition: To use one hold for two limbs.

title: Merkel
definition: To retrieve another climbers gear because he or she is unable to or because it would be more convenient.

title: Moat
definition: A crevasse that forms where the glacier pulls away from a rock formation.

title: Mono
definition: (French monodoigt 'single finger') A climbing hold, typically a pocket or hueco, that only has enough room for one finger.

title: Mountain rescue
definition: The search and rescue activities that occur in a mountainous environment, although the term sometimes also applies to search and rescue in other wilderness environments. Also see rescue doctrine.

title: Move
definition: Application of a specific climbing technique to progress on a climb.

title: Moving together
definition: Method of climbing – used on easy Alpine ground – in which two or more climbers climb at the same time with running belays between them and fixed belays not being used. Similar to simulclimbing, a technique for steeper terrain.

title: Multi-pitch climbing
definition: Climbing on routes that are too long for a single belay rope.

title: Munter hitch
definition: A simple hitch that is often used for belaying without a mechanical belay device. Otherwise known as an Italian hitch or a friction hitch.

title: Naturals
definition: In a climbing gym: the natural features of the wall texture itself, those which can be climbed on but are not bolt-on holds.[21][22]

title: Névé
definition: Permanent granular ice formed by repeated freeze-thaw cycles.

title: No-hand rest
definition: An entirely leg-supported resting position during climbing that does not require hands on the rock.

title: Nub
definition: A little hold that only a few fingers can grip, or the tips of the toes.

title: Nunatak
definition: A mountain or rock that protrudes through an ice field.

title: Nut
definition: A metal wedge attached to a wire loop that is inserted into cracks for protection. See hexcentric.

title: Nut Key or nut tool
definition: See Cleaning Tool.

title: Ninja feet
definition: The quiet, deliberate, and precise placement of toes upon a foothold.

title: Objective danger
definition: Danger in a climbing situation which comes from hazards inherent in the location of the climb, not depending on the climber's skill level. Most often these involve falling rock or ice, or avalanches.

title: Off belay
definition: Called by a climber when requesting that the belayer remove belay equipment from the climbing rope (for example, when cleaning top protection from a lead route).  Replied to with Belay off.

title: Off-width
definition: A crack that is too wide for effective hand or foot jams, but is not as large as a chimney.

title: On belay
definition: What an American climber calls when he is ready to be belayed.  Replied to with Belay on.

title: On-sight
definition: A clean ascent, with no prior practice or beta. For ascents on the first attempt with receiving beta see flash.

title: Open book
definition: An inside angle in the rock. See also dihedral.

title: Overhang
definition: A section of rock or ice that is angled beyond vertical. See roof.

title: Orangutan
definition: In orangutan position, one's back is facing the wall and has a posture resembling an orangutan hanging with limbs outstretched. The orangutan is primarily used for horizontal traversal. In a left traversal, the sequence starts by threading one's right foot and right hand between the placements of one's left foot and left hand to reach the next supportive rock features. The exit sequence is symmetric.

title: Panic Bear
definition: A panicking novice climber clinging to handholds while searching desperately for a foothold.

title: Peak-bagging
definition: To systematically attain designated summits under prescribed conditions.

title: Peel
definition: To fall.

title: Peg
definition: A piton.

title: Pendulum
definition:
Swinging on taut rope to reach the next hold in a pendulum traverse.
A swing during a fall when the last piece of protection is far to one side.

title: Personal Anchor System (PAS)
definition: Adjustable attachment point from climber to anchor.  Allows for building anchors, cleaning routes and rappeling to be done efficiently and faster.

title: Pickets
definition: Long, tubular rods driven into snow to provide a quick anchor.

title: Pied à main
definition: A movement where the foot is placed on the same hold as the hand.

title: Pied à plat
definition: A crampon technique in the French style: to climb on high-angle ice with feet flat on the ice (as opposed to front-pointing).

title: Pied assis
definition: A crampon technique in the French style: to rest on high-angle ice with one foot tucked under the buttocks, toes pointed straight down-slope.

title: Pied d'Elephant
definition: A short, light sleeping bag covering the lower half of the body only. It is designed to be used in connection with a down jacket for lightweight bivvies.

title: Pied en canard
definition: A crampon technique in the French style: to walk on moderate-angle ice with toes pointed outward; literally, 'duck-footed'.

title: Pied marche
definition: A crampon technique in the French style: to walk on low-angle ice with toes pointed straight ahead.

title: Picknick stop
definition: A No-hand rest.

title: Pinch Hold
definition: This is a hold where you must pinch it to hold on. They come in various sizes.

title: Pinkpoint
definition: To complete a lead climb without falling or resting on the rope (hangdogging), but with pre-placed protection and carabiners. Also see clean and redpoint.

title: Pitch
definition: In the strictest climbing definition, a pitch is considered one rope length 50–60 metres (160–200 ft). However, in guide books and route descriptions, a pitch is the portion of a climb between two belay points.

title: Piton
definition: A flat or angled metal blade of steel which incorporates a clipping hole for a carabiner or a ring in its body. A piton is typically used in aid-climbing and an appropriate size and shape is hammered into a thin crack in the rock and preferably removed by the last team member.

title: Piton catcher
definition: Clip-on string fastened to piton when inserting or removing, so as to avoid loss.

title: Plunge step
definition: An aggressive step pattern for descending on hard or steep angle snow.

title: Pof
definition: An alternative to chalk made from pine resin. Popular in Fontainebleau but discouraged (or actively forbidden) everywhere else since it deposits a thick, shiny resin layer on the rock and friction can only be achieved by using more pof.

title: Polish
definition: On popular routes, the sheer passage of traffic can polish the rock to such an extent as to make the climbing much more difficult. This is most noticeable at the crux, and more common on certain rock types.

title: Poop tube
definition: Container for carrying out your feces during multi-day climb. The Poop Tube is made of PVC tubing, with a sealed end at the bottom and a screw top. It has a loop attaching screw top to the body of the tube and a webbing so it can be clipped below the haul bag.[23][24]

title: Positive
definition: A hold or part of a hold, having a surface facing upwards, or away from the direction it is pulled, facilitating use. Positive hold is an opposite to a sloper.

title: Pressure Breathing
definition: Forcefully exhaling to facilitate O2/CO2 exchange at altitude. Also called the "Whittaker wheeze".

title: Problem
definition: Boulder problem or problem is used in bouldering to indicate the path that a climber takes in order to complete the climb. Same as route in roped climbing.

title: Project
definition:
A potential new route or bouldering problem that is being attempted, but has not seen a first ascent yet.
An established route or bouldering problem that an individual is repeatedly attempting to ascend over a period of time, but has not been successfully been sent by that climber. Sometimes slang in the form proj.

title: Protection
definition:
Process of setting equipment or anchors for safety.
Equipment or anchors used for arresting falls. Commonly known as Pro.

title: Prusik
definition:
A knot used for ascending a rope.  It is named after Dr. Karl Prusik, the Austrian mountaineer who developed this knot in 1931.
To use a Prusik knot for ascending a rope.

title: Pseudo Leading
definition: To climb a wall Toprope with having another rope connected to the climber, for practice of Lead climbing clipping. The other rope is normally not connected to any belayer below and is only there to practice the clipping. Usually practiced while learning how to Lead Climb.  Also commonly  referred to as "mock leading".

title: Psychological protection
definition: A piece of protection that everyone knows will not hold a fall, but makes the climber feel better about having gear beneath them anyhow.

title: Pumped
definition:
To have such an accumulation of metabolic waste products in the forearm, that forming even a basic grip becomes impossible.  A climber who is pumped will find it difficult to hold on, and may struggle to lift or clip a rope.
(Psychology) A feeling of anticipation and energy before a challenging climb.

title: Punter
definition: An over-ambitious and under-prepared climber.

title: Purchase
definition: To have a solid grip on a hold or feature.  "I had good purchase on that jug."

title: Quickdraw
definition: Used to attach a freely running rope to anchors or chocks. Sometimes called quickies, draws, or extenders.

title: Quicklink
definition: A screw-type oval-shape stainless steel carabiner which is smaller than normal oval-shape biner, particularly used for attaching to the chains of the master anchor. Also known as a maillon or maillon rapide.

title: Rack
definition:
The set of equipment carried up a climb; also, the part of a harness (consisting of several plastic loops) where equipment is hung, ready to be used.
Also a type of descender consisisting of bars mounted on a "U" shaped chassis.

title: Rappel
definition: The process by which a climber may descend on a fixed rope using a friction device. Also known as abseil or roping down.

title: RB
definition: A removable bolt, similar in concept to a sliding nut, but shaped to fit into a drilled hole.

title: Rebolting
definition: The replacement of bolts on an existing climb.

title: Redpoint
definition: Redpointing a route means free-climbing it by leading, after having practiced the route beforehand (either by hangdogging or top roping). Also see clean and pinkpoint.

title: Rest step
definition: Energy-saving technique where unweighted (uphill) leg is rested between each forward step, sometimes by "locking" knee of rear leg.

title: Retro-bolting
definition: The addition of bolts to an existing climb which has already been ascended using natural protection.

title: Rodeo clipping
definition: To clip into the first piece of protection from the ground by swinging a loop of rope so that it is caught by a carabiner.  This can only be done when the first piece of gear is already placed.

title: Roof
definition: A steep overhang which transitions sharply into shallower climbing often blocking direct sight of the feet causing the climber to find footholds blindly.

title: Rope
definition: A basic item of climbing equipment that physically connects the climber to the belayer.

title: Rope gun
definition: The most capable climber in the group. The person who can get the rope up there for the rest of the party.

title: Rope jumping
definition: Jumping from objects using rock climbing equipment.

title: Rope team
definition: Also roped team or roped party. Team of mountaineers or climbers joined together by a safety rope.

title: Rose (also called rose move)
definition: An extreme cross-through reach in which the crossing arm goes behind the other arm, and it is so far extended that the body is forced to twist until it ends up facing away from the rock. It was introduced by Antoine Le Menestrel, who used it to climb a route in Buoux, called La rose et le vampire.[26][27]

title: Route
definition: The path of a particular climb, or a predefined set of moves.

title: RP
definition: A small nut, named after Roland Pauligk. Not certified for sale in Europe.

title: Runner
definition:
In the US, runners are slings, made of nylon and nylon/blend materials, used by climbers for a multitude of purposes.
In the UK, runners, or running belays, refer to any item of gear placed by the lead climber to reduce the length of a fall.

title: Runout
definition:
A lengthy distance between two points of protection which in some, but not all, cases might be perceived as frightening or dangerous.  May also be used as an adjective to describe a route, or a section of a route.
A long portion of a route with minimal protection.

title: RURP
definition: Acronym, stands for Realized Ultimate Reality Piton.  Miniature, postage-stamp sized piton originally designed by Yvon Chouinard

title: Saddle
definition: A high pass between two peaks, larger than a col.

title: Sandbag
definition: A climb which receives a much lower grade than deserved.  Also used as a verb when referring to the act of describing a climbing route as easier than it actually is.

title: Sardar or Sirdar
definition: Head Sherpa mountain guide.

title: 'scend
definition: contraction of the word ascend, past tense: 'scended.  See also send.

title: Scheissegrippen
definition: The intense feeling of disappointment when finding a difficult crux after a jug or good handhold.

title: Scrambling
definition: A type of climbing somewhere between hiking and graded rock climbing.

title: Screamer
definition:
A long and loud fall.
A nylon webbing structure consisting of one large loop sewn in multiple places to make a shorter length. The stitch-points are intentionally sewn with less than maximum possible strength. The screamer is attached with carabiners between an anchor point, particularly one of dubious strength, and the climber. In the event of a fall the stitching of the sewn sections is designed to rip apart, absorbing some of the fall energy and decelerating the climber, thereby reducing the overall shock load on the dubious anchor.  Screamer is a brand name of Yates Mountaineering.

title: Scree
definition: Small, loose, broken rocks, often at the base of a cliff. Also an area or slope covered in scree.  Scree is distinguished from Talus by its smaller size and looser configuration.

title: Screw on
definition: A small climbing hold, screwed onto the wall in climbing gyms. Can be used for feet in a route regardless of its colour. Also referred to as a foot chip, chip or micro.

title: Second
definition: A climber who follows the lead, or first, climber.

title: Self-Arrest
definition: The act of planting the pick of your ice axe into the snow to arrest a fall in the event of a slip.  Also a method of stopping in a controlled glissade.

title: Self-Belay
definition: To perform belaying for oneself.

title: Send
definition: To cleanly complete a route. i.e. on-sight, flash, redpoint. See also 'scend.

title: Serac
definition: A large ice tower.

title: SERENE
definition: Acronym for the important points to consider when building anchors. The acronym stands for Strong, Equalised, Redundant, Efficient, No Extension. See also ERNEST.

title: Sewing-machine leg
definition: The involuntary vibration of one or both legs resulting from fatigue or panic. Also known as scissor leg, Elvis Presley syndrome, or disco knee. Can often be remedied by bringing the heel of the offending leg down, changing the muscles used to support the weight of the climber

title: Sharp end
definition: The end of the belay rope that is attached to the lead climber.  Being on the sharp end refers to the act of lead climbing, which is considered more psychologically demanding than top-roping or following, since it may involve more route-finding, as well as the possibility of longer, more consequential falls.

title: Sherpa
definition: A Sherpa is a person of the ethnic group of the same name that is located in the Himalayan Mountains. Also a generic term for mountaineering porters in Nepal (usually those working at or above base camp) regardless of their ethnic group

title: Short fixing
definition: A traditionally-belayed lead climber reaches a new belay station, creates an anchor, tying the lead rope off to the anchor.  The climber then switches over to self-belaying and continues to climb. Meanwhile, the second climber ascends the fixed rope using ascenders (aka Jugging) and cleans the pitch. When the second reaches the belay, he or she anchors in and starts to belay the leader in the traditional way again. When the leader reaches the next belay the process is repeated.

title: Side pull
definition: A hold that needs to be gripped with a sideways pull towards the body.

title: Simul climbing
definition: A technique where both climbers move simultaneously upward with the leader placing protection which the second removes as they advance. A device known as a Tibloc which allows the rope to only move in a single direction is sometimes used to prevent the second climber from accidentally pulling the lead climber off should the second slip.[28]

title: Single Rope Technique (SRT)
definition: The use of a single rope where one or both ends of the rope are attached to fixed anchor points.

title: Sit and spin
definition: A method of starting a rappel from a cliff edge, accomplished by sitting with legs over the edge and then spinning around to face the cliff while planting feet on the face.

title: Sit start
definition: Starting a climb from a position in which the climber is sitting on the floor. This is common in climbing gyms in order to fit an extra move into the climb. Noted as SS or SDS in some topo guides and commonly used on Reddit in the community /r/climbing.

title: Skittling
definition: Climbing without following any specific color in a gym with color-designated routes/problems. Also referred to as "climbing the rainbow," since any and all colors of holds are used.

title: Skyhook
definition: A small hook which gives hold on small protrusions on watery and slippery grips. They are most often used for placements, often extremely marginal, in aid climbing, although they also feature in some extreme free routes. Additionally, the skyhook can be attached to the harness, thus allowing the climber to rest, or held in one or both hands to hold a grip.

title: Slab
definition: A relatively low-angle (significantly less than vertical) section of rock, usually with few large features. Requires slab climbing techniques.

title: Slab climbing
definition: A particular type of rock climbing, and its associated techniques, involved in climbing rock that is less than vertical. The emphasis is on balance, footwork, and making use of very small features or rough spots on the rock for friction.

title: Slack
definition: Portion of rope that is not taut, preferably minimized during belay.

title: Slap
definition: An attempt at a route or move. "I'll give that a slap." or "What a hard slap; I'm pumped."

title: SLCD
definition: Abbreviation for spring-loaded camming device, a type of protection device. These are better known by the term cam.

title: Sling
definition: Webbing sewn, or tied, into a loop.

title: Sloppy Plopping
definition: Poor footwork [Northumberland climbing slang] as in "nae sloppy ploppin'", i.e. 'you'll need accurate footwork to have any chance of flashing this'.

title: Sloper
definition: A sloping hold with very little positive surface. A sloper is comparable to palming a basketball.

title: Smearing
definition: To use friction on the sole of the climbing shoe, in the absence of any useful footholds.

title: Smedging
definition: Smearing on an edge, especially on a dime edge or any linear hold that is too small to stand on or use as an ordinary positive hold.

title: Snarg
definition: A type of tubular ice screw that is inserted by hammering.

title: Snow fluke
definition: An angled aluminium plate attached to a metal cable. The fluke is buried into snow, typically used as a deadman anchor.

title: Solo climbing
definition: Setting and cleaning one's own protection on an ascent; climbing by oneself.

title: Soupy
definition: A hold that is wet and slimy from water or some other source.

title: Spinner
definition: In indoor climbing, a hold that is not secure and spins in place when weight is applied.

title: Spike
definition: See horn.

title: Splitter
definition: Describes a clean crack with perfectly parallel sides, usually in an otherwise blank face.  Generalized to refer to any great climb, happy situation, or even favorable weather.

title: Sport climbing
definition: A style of climbing where form, technical (or gymnastic) ability and strength are more emphasized over exploration, self-reliance and the exhilaration of the inherent dangers involved in the sport. Sport climbing routes tend to be well protected with pre-placed bolt-anchors and lends itself well to competitive climbing.

title: Spotting
definition: A method of protection commonly used during bouldering or before the leader has placed a piece of protection. The spotter stands beneath the climber, ready to absorb the energy of a fall and direct him away from any hazards.

title: Sprag
definition: A type of hand position where the fingers and thumb are opposed.

title: Spraying
definition: Giving unwanted – and unasked-for – beta to a fellow climber.  Also, excessive, overly prominent, or boorish proclamation of one's own (often exaggerated) skills or exploits.

title: Static
definition: Of a style of climbing or specific move, not dynamic.  In general this entails movement of a limb to a new hold without the simultaneous transfer of weight. Instead weight transfer occurs after the limb has moved.

title: Static rope
definition: A non-elastic rope. Compare with dynamic rope.

title: Steep
definition: Descriptive of any climbing face that is angled beyond vertical. See overhang.

title: Stem
definition:
The simultaneous use of two widely spaced footholds.
Climbing using two faces that are at an angle less than 180° to each other.

title: Step cutting
definition: Scooping steps out of snow or ice with the adze of an ice axe.

title: Step kicking
definition: Scooping and stamping steps out of soft snow with the feet.

title: Sticht plate
definition: A belay device consisting of a flat plate with a pair of slots. Named after the inventor Fritz Sticht.

title: Stick clip
definition: A long stick or extendable pole on the end of which a climber can affix a quickdraw. It allows the climber to clip a quickdraw to the first bolt on a sport climb while still standing on the ground. This is especially useful if the first bolt is high up, and out of the comfort zone of the climber. A stick clip can be bought, easily made or even improvised when needed. Ethically controversial in some communities.

title: Sticky rubber
definition: Rubber with enhanced frictional properties used on the soles of climbing shoes; originally introduced in the 1980s (on Boreal's Firé shoes) but now ubiquitous.

title: Stopper
definition:
A wedge-shaped nut made by Black Diamond.
A knot used to prevent the rope running through a piece of equipment.

title: Summit
definition:
The high point of a mountain or peak.
To reach such a high point.

title: Swami Belt
definition: A kind of proto-climbing harness consisting of a long length of tubular webbing wrapped several times around the climbers body and secured with a water knot.  Largely eschewed today in favor of commercial harnesses.

title: Sweeper
definition: Refers to the last member or the tail of a climbing group. The sweeper's task is to spot and retrieve things that may have accidentally fallen from the preceding climbers; to make sure that no mess or gear is left behind; and to make sure that the rear is keeping up with the whole team. The term sweeper, a Filipino contribution to mountaineering vocabulary, was introduced in 1998 and was inspired by the Cleaner, a character in the 1990 film Nikita (also known as La Femme Nikita) by Luc Besson.

title: Swinging-lieback
definition: A dynamic form of the lieback, described above, rotating off one foot while maintaining a grip with one hand, then grabbing a high handhold at the deadpoint of the swing with the other hand. This move is frequently reversible, unlike more aerial dynos.

title: Switcharoo
definition: To swap limbs on a particular hold.  Not to be confused with matching.

title: Take
definition: Called by a climber when requesting that the belayer remove all slack. See hang dogging.

title: Talus
definition: An area of large rock fragments on a mountainside that may vary from house-size to as small as a small backpack. The area, if older and consolidated, may be stable, or the rocks may be precariously balanced.  Talus is distinguished from scree in that it is larger and may feature solid interlocking of the rocks, while scree is by definition loose.

title: Teabagging
definition: When, after a whipper, or long fall, a climber falls past their belayer, who is generally lifted up off the ground.

title: Technical climbing
definition: Climbing involving a rope and some means of protection, as opposed to scrambling or glacier travel.

title: Technical
definition: A term often used to describe very technical sequences of moves and / or the degree of ingenuity and creativity required to protect a route. Difficulty ratings of climbs often is a combination of technicality of a climb and the endurance or strength necessary to complete it.

title: Technique
definition: Specialized moves given names to help communicate what to do to another person.

title: Tendu
definition: From the French word meaning outstretched. In this grip the fingers are close to the position when the hand is open.  The relative angle between the finger bones is gradual. The load applied is coming from tension in the forearm muscles.

title: Tension
definition: A technique for maintaining balance using a taut rope through a point of protection.

title: Testpiece
definition: A climb that is representative of the hardest, best climbs in an area.

title: Thread
definition: A runner created by threading a sling around a jammed block or through a hole in the rock.

title: Thrutching
definition: Make progress by squeezing into a space and wriggling against opposing rock surfaces.

title: Tie-In Points
definition: The leg straps and waist belt create two loops connecting the belay loop.  The points which you tie in at.  Also known as soft loops.

title: Toe hook
definition:
Toe hook 
A toe hook is securing the upper side of the toes on a hold.  It helps pull the body inwards—towards the wall.  The toe hook is often used on overhanging rock where it helps to keep the body from swinging away from the wall.

title: Top rope
definition: To belay from a fixed anchor point above the climb. Top-roping requires easy access to the top of the climb, by means of a footpath or scrambling.

title: Top-out
definition: To complete a route by ascending over the top of the structure being climbed.

title: Track
definition: To use holds specified out for you in any route, usually used in gym climbing.

title: Traditional climbing
definition: A style of climbing that emphasizes the adventure and exploratory nature of climbing. While sport climbers generally will use pre-placed protection ("bolts"), traditional (or "trad") climbers will place their own protection as they climb, generally carried with them on a rack.

title: Training
definition: Getting prepared to climb on difficult mountains.

title: Tramming
definition: A technique that is typically used while lowering and cleaning gear from an overhanging and/or traversing route.  A quickdraw is clipped between the climber's harness and the rope that is threaded through the gear.  As the climber is lowered by the belayer, the quickdraw holds the cleaner close to the wall and following the line of the route.  Without the quickdraw, the climber would lower straight down, further and further from the remaining gear to be cleaned. Also known as trolleying.

title: Traverse
definition:
To climb in a horizontal direction.
A section of a route that requires progress in a horizontal direction.
A Tyrolean traverse is crossing a chasm using a rope anchored at both ends.
A pendulum traverse involves swinging across a wall or chasm while suspended from a rope affixed above the climber.

title: Tricam
definition: A simple camming protection device that has no moving parts.

title: Tuber
definition: A belay device.

title: Tufa
definition: A limestone rib formation that protrudes from the wall which can sometimes fit within the pinching grasp of a climber's hand; alternatively: a plastic, bolted on bouldering hold designed to replicate such a formation on an indoor climbing wall.

title: Twin Ropes
definition: System where the climber is using two thin ropes instead of one thicker one, but unlike double ropes twin ropes have to be clipped through the same biner for each piece of protection. Twin ropes are often used by trad and alpine climbers. They allow full pitch rappelling and help reducing the chances for accidental cutting of the rope by sharp rock edges.[12]

title: Two man stand
definition: An outdated climbing technique where one climber stands on the shoulders of another climber as an assist in climbing.

title: Udge
definition: Technique needed to make slow upwards progress on holdless rock, especially off-width cracks.[29]

title: Undercling
definition: A hold which is gripped with the palm of the hand facing upwards

title: Übergrippen
definition: The intense feeling of relief when finding a jug or good handhold after a difficult Crux. [30][31][32]

title: "V"-grade
definition: A technical grading system for bouldering problems, invented by John Sherman.

title: V-thread
definition: A type of abseiling point used especially in winter and ice climbing. Also called abalakov thread.

title: Verglas
definition: A thin coating of ice that forms over rocks when rainfall or melting snow freezes on rock. Hard to climb on as there is insufficient depth for crampons to have reliable penetration. See also clear ice and glaze ice.

title: Volume
definition: A large, hollow bolted-on bouldering hold.

title: WAD
definition: Originating in Sheffield, a WAD is a "super climber" or climber who is on-sighting 7c+.

title: Wand
definition: A bamboo stick with a small flag on top used to mark paths over glaciers and snow fields.

title: Webbing
definition: Hollow and flat nylon strip, mainly used to make slings.

title: Webolette
definition: A piece of webbing with eyes sewn into the ends which can be used in place of a cordelette.

title: Weighting
definition: As in, "weighting the rope." Any time the rope takes the weight of the climber. This can happen during a minor fall, a whipper (long fall), or simply by resting while hanging on the belay rope (see also hangdogging).

title: Whipper
definition: A lead fall from above and to the side of the last clip, whipping oneself downwards and in an arc. Has come to denote any fall beyond the last placed or clipped piece of protection.

title: Wired
definition: A route or sequence that a climber has rehearsed extensively and thus ascends with ease. See dialled.

title: Wires
definition: See nuts.

title: Wolf moon
definition: To complete a lead climb during night time.

title: Woodie
definition: A home made climbing wall. Often specifically a hybrid between a climbing wall and a fingerboard. Specifically called such because of the wooden panels (usually left unpainted) used to attach the climbing holds to.

title: X (Protection Rating)
definition: A rating from the Yosemite Decimal System given to climbs that have very poor or no protection. These climbs often present risk of serious injury or death if a fall were to occur, even if the climb is properly protected.

title: Xeno
definition: A hold appearing to be composed of a different type of rock than the surrounding face.

title: Yabo
definition: Another name for a Sit start, a 'Yabo start' was named after John 'Yabo' Yablonski.[33]

title: Yard up
definition: To pull on the rope to make upward progress, often with assistance from the belayer. This may be done to bypass a crux, or to quickly regain ground lost after a fall without re-climbing the section. AKA to "jug up" the rope.

title: Yosemite Decimal System
definition: A numerical system for rating the difficulty of walks, hikes, and climbs in the United States. The rock climbing (5.x) portion of the scale is the most common climb grading system used in the US. The scale starts with the easiest grades at 5.0 and is open-ended on the harder end. As of  September 2017[update], the most difficult grade was 5.15d.

title: zawn
definition: In the UK, a deep, narrow inlet in a sea-cliff, filled by the sea at high tides.

title: Z-clipping
definition: Clipping into a piece of protection with the segment of rope from beneath the previous piece of protection, resulting in a potentially dangerous tangled configuration of the belay rope. If not fixed can result in high drag.

title: Zipper fall
definition: A fall in which each piece of protection fails in turn.  In some cases when the rope comes taut during a fall, the protection can fail from the bottom up, especially if the first piece was not placed to account for outward and/or upward force.

title: Z-pulley
definition: Also Z-system. A particular configuration of rope, anchors, and pulleys typically used to extricate a climber after falling into a crevasse.
